comments.body: Is this supposed to pass or fail validation?

> Is this supposed to pass or fail validation?

Fail.  It uses some common testing methods and that secret is expected to fail.
Ok, I see the comment above now. Renaming the case would help. `~.invalidname` or something. Esp. since `.dotfile` is going to be legal.

> Ok, I see the comment above now. Renaming the case would help. ~.invalidname or something. Esp. since .dotfile is going to be legal.

Looks the library wants to test creates by using one valid example and many invalid examples, so renaming the method isn't accurate.

> Looks the library wants to test creates by using one valid example and many invalid examples, so renaming the method isn't accurate.

I got hung up by that one too.  Gonna make an issue for it.
Not your problem but I find the signature of TestCreate to be extremely unreadable

> On Apr 28, 2015, at 12:32 PM, Paul Morie notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> In pkg/registry/secret/etcd/etcd_test.go:
> 
> > -           Namespace: api.NamespaceDefault,
> > -       },
> > -       Data: map[string][]byte{
> > -           "test": []byte("data"),
> > -       },
> > -   }
> >   +}
> >   +
> >   +func TestCreate(t *testing.T) {
> > -   fakeEtcdClient, helper := newHelper(t)
> > -   storage := NewStorage(helper)
> > -   test := resttest.New(t, storage, fakeEtcdClient.SetError)
> > -   secret := validNewSecret("foo")
> > -   secret.Name = ""
> > -   secret.GenerateName = "foo-"
> > -   test.TestCreate(
> >   Not your problem but I find the signature of TestCreate to be extremely unreadable
> 
> Noted, people with time to come up with a better one are encouraged to provide pulls to improve it...
